title: Does a novel have to have a main character? - Quora

response.answer_text: Short answer no. Longer answer, well… There are 3 kinds of characters that can be possible centers for a story: hero, protagonist, and main character. And yes, they’re all different. A hero is someone who’s morally good. (generally speaking) A protagonist is the one we as the reader/watcher/listener are rooting for to succeed. But the main character is simply the lens through which we access the story. An example of these three things being different within the same story is the Great Gatsby. Gatsby is the protagonist, but he’s not a hero as he’s not very moral, and Nick Caraway (one of his friends) is actually the MC, because the book is told in his perspective as the biggest third wheel in fictional history. So, can you tell a story without a person who’s telling the story? I’ve read many books with multiple MC’s, where the point of view shifts from person to person, but I can’t say that I’ve read a book with the other possibility; that there is no character telling the story nor pushing it forward at all. Hm… I only say that a story doesn’t have to have an MC because I think it’s possible, but it’s honestly blowing my mind to try and imagine one. Because even stories with the narrator as not any of the characters, there’s still an MC (the first that comes to mind is 1984, which is implied to be told by someone who lives long after the main character of the story, Winston, is dead.) If you want, I listen to this writing advice podcast where they discussed this very topic in a recent episode. Rather than re-listen to it, I’ll just give you the link if you’re interested on some actual experts’ take (and not a rando on the internet, lol.) 13.1: Hero, Protagonist, Main Character

I would say yes, Every story needs a main character! He/she is the one that holds the story together. EX: Bob has just purchased a 2 million dollar home, he had been lucky and won the lottery! The day that he and his family left their previous home, with only 2 bedrooms and 5 sons, they were elated! His wife Martha was so overjoyed, and so were the boys. Finally Bob could quit his job as manager of a supermarket and enjoy his family. . Bob and Martha had never bought lottery tickets before, but Bob was in a convenience store buying candy for the boys when he saw the bright red and gray scratch off ticket, the ticket seemed to beckon to him. An instant win for 5 million! Life would be good for he and his family from now on.. Summary, Bob and Martha had been struggling with 5 children and only 2 bedrooms, Bob is the main character, Martha is the secondary main character. there is no requirement to introduce the 5 children in the story line…unless we give them a first name. ..BILLY, BAILEY, BAXTER, BRIAN, AND BRICE

Not necessarily but it’s easier for your readers to engage if they have at east one person with whom they can identify. You could write a story with a huge cast of characters but I would still make at least one of them more central to the story than the others. Or, if I split the book between locations I would have a main character or a small group of core characters in each location that my reader could grow to care about.

No, it does not. Your novel can be whatever you like, or however you want it to be. There are no rules. Look up postmodernism and popular books in this genre. As a theory it says that chaos is all around us and all we can do is exist within it. It can have very interesting implications when it comes to literature. There is no need for a central character, plot or theme, there does not need to be any widely accepted structure to your book even. Hope this helps!

no a novel like “It” or “Dune” or infinite jest, doesnt really have a single main character, they can be more dynamic than what people are used to. but people like what their used to so writers tend to give the people what they want. a central main character that overcomes all odds who’s relatable. and it’s less confusing and doesnt take away from the book’s central idea or themes.

Not always. But if you are going down the route of writing about a group of people and how they interact, or how one incident/accident/happening/day affects a number of people who would otherwise never meet, then you have to take the time to get into each character’s head separately because all characters - especially ones not linked by family/marriage/sex/etc, will have totally different views from each other, and will deal with situations very differently to the next person.
